If the second of three points is strictly between the other two, the angle at that point
is π.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] {p₁ p₂ p₃ : P}, Sbtw ℝ p₁ p₂ p₃ → EuclideanGeometry.angle p₁ p₂ p₃ = Real.pi
name: Sbtw.angle₁₂₃_eq_pi
docString:
If the second of three points is strictly between the other two, the angle at that point
is π.

In a triangle, the sum of the angles at any two vertices is equal to π.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] {p1 p2 p3 : P},
  p2 ≠ p1 →
    p3 ≠ p1 →
      EuclideanGeometry.angle p1 p2 p3 + EuclideanGeometry.angle p2 p3 p1 + EuclideanGeometry.angle p3 p1 p2 = Real.pi
name: EuclideanGeometry.angle_add_angle_add_angle_eq_pi
docString: In a triangle, the sum of the angles at any two vertices is equal to π.

This theorem is stating the **sum of the angles of a triangle** theorem from Euclidean Geometry, which states that for any given triangle (which could possibly degenerate into a line) with vertices p1, p2, and p3 in a 2-dimensional vector space V over the real numbers ℝ, the sum of the oriented angles at these points is always equal to π, given that these points are distinct from each other. The oriented angles are calculated using the function `EuclideanGeometry.oangle`. If the underlying space has more than two dimensions, this theorem doesn't apply.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] [inst_4 : Module.Oriented ℝ V (Fin 2)]
  [inst_5 : Fact (FiniteDimensional.finrank ℝ V = 2)] {p1 p2 p3 : P},
  p2 ≠ p1 →
    p3 ≠ p2 →
      p1 ≠ p3 →
        EuclideanGeometry.oangle p1 p2 p3 + EuclideanGeometry.oangle p2 p3 p1 + EuclideanGeometry.oangle p3 p1 p2 =
          ↑Real.pi
name: EuclideanGeometry.oangle_add_oangle_add_oangle_eq_pi
docString: This theorem is stating the **sum of the angles of a triangle** theorem from Euclidean Geometry, which states that for any given triangle (which could possibly degenerate into a line) with vertices p1, p2, and p3 in a 2-dimensional vector space V over the real numbers ℝ, the sum of the oriented angles at these points is always equal to π, given that these points are distinct from each other. The oriented angles are calculated using the function `EuclideanGeometry.oangle`. If the underlying space has more than two dimensions, this theorem doesn't apply.

An angle in a right-angled triangle is at most `π / 2`.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] {p₁ p₂ p₃ : P},
  EuclideanGeometry.angle p₁ p₂ p₃ = Real.pi / 2 → EuclideanGeometry.angle p₂ p₃ p₁ ≤ Real.pi / 2
name: EuclideanGeometry.angle_le_pi_div_two_of_angle_eq_pi_div_two
docString: An angle in a right-angled triangle is at most `π / 2`.

In Euclidean geometry, the sum of the oriented angles at distinct points in a triangle is equal to π.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] [inst_4 : Module.Oriented ℝ V (Fin 2)]
  [inst_5 : Fact (FiniteDimensional.finrank ℝ V = 2)] {p1 p2 p3 : P},
  p2 ≠ p1 →
    p3 ≠ p2 →
      p1 ≠ p3 →
        EuclideanGeometry.oangle p1 p2 p3 + EuclideanGeometry.oangle p2 p3 p1 + EuclideanGeometry.oangle p3 p1 p2 =
          ↑Real.pi
name: EuclideanGeometry.oangle_add_oangle_add_oangle_eq_pi
docString: In Euclidean geometry, the sum of the oriented angles at distinct points in a triangle is equal to π.

This theorem states that in the context of Euclidean geometry, specifically in a 2-dimensional space modeled by an inner product space over the real numbers, the angle at the vertex of an isosceles triangle inscribed in a sphere is equal to the constant pi (π) minus twice the base angle. This base angle is considered in an oriented angle-at-a-point form where the vertex is taken as the center of the sphere. The points forming the isosceles triangle are subject to conditions that they are distinct and lie on the sphere. Here, the orientation of the 2-dimensional vector space and the measure of angles are carried out in accordance with the real numbers. The angles are expressed in terms of `EuclideanGeometry.oangle`, which represents an oriented angle between three points.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] [hd2 : Fact (FiniteDimensional.finrank ℝ V = 2)] [inst_4 : Module.Oriented ℝ V (Fin 2)]
  {s : EuclideanGeometry.Sphere P} {p₁ p₂ : P},
  p₁ ∈ s →
    p₂ ∈ s → p₁ ≠ p₂ → EuclideanGeometry.oangle p₁ s.center p₂ = ↑Real.pi - 2 • EuclideanGeometry.oangle s.center p₂ p₁
name: EuclideanGeometry.Sphere.oangle_eq_pi_sub_two_zsmul_oangle_center_left
docString: This theorem states that in the context of Euclidean geometry, specifically in a 2-dimensional space modeled by an inner product space over the real numbers, the angle at the vertex of an isosceles triangle inscribed in a sphere is equal to the constant pi (π) minus twice the base angle. This base angle is considered in an oriented angle-at-a-point form where the vertex is taken as the center of the sphere. The points forming the isosceles triangle are subject to conditions that they are distinct and lie on the sphere. Here, the orientation of the 2-dimensional vector space and the measure of angles are carried out in accordance with the real numbers. The angles are expressed in terms of `EuclideanGeometry.oangle`, which represents an oriented angle between three points.

Given three nonzero vectors, adding the angles between them in cyclic order, with the second
vector in each angle negated, results in π. If the vectors add to 0, this is a version of the
sum of the angles of a triangle.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] [inst_2 : Fact (Module.finrank ℝ V = 2)]
  (o : Orientation ℝ V (Fin 2)) {x y z : V},
  x ≠ 0 → y ≠ 0 → z ≠ 0 → o.oangle x (-y) + o.oangle y (-z) + o.oangle z (-x) = ↑Real.pi
name: Orientation.oangle_add_cyc3_neg_right
docString:
Given three nonzero vectors, adding the angles between them in cyclic order, with the second
vector in each angle negated, results in π. If the vectors add to 0, this is a version of the
sum of the angles of a triangle.

Twice a base angle of an isosceles triangle with apex at the center of a circle, plus twice
the angle at the apex of a triangle with the same base but apex on the circle, equals `π`.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] [hd2 : Fact (Module.finrank ℝ V = 2)] [inst_4 : Module.Oriented ℝ V (Fin 2)]
  {s : EuclideanGeometry.Sphere P} {p₁ p₂ p₃ : P},
  p₁ ∈ s →
    p₂ ∈ s →
      p₃ ∈ s →
        p₂ ≠ p₁ →
          p₂ ≠ p₃ →
            p₁ ≠ p₃ → 2 • EuclideanGeometry.oangle p₃ p₁ s.center + 2 • EuclideanGeometry.oangle p₁ p₂ p₃ = ↑Real.pi
name: EuclideanGeometry.Sphere.two_zsmul_oangle_center_add_two_zsmul_oangle_eq_pi
docString:
Twice a base angle of an isosceles triangle with apex at the center of a circle, plus twice
the angle at the apex of a triangle with the same base but apex on the circle, equals `π`.

If the second of three points is strictly between the other two, the angle at that point
(reversed) is π.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] {p₁ p₂ p₃ : P}, Sbtw ℝ p₁ p₂ p₃ → EuclideanGeometry.angle p₃ p₂ p₁ = Real.pi
name: Sbtw.angle₃₂₁_eq_pi
docString:
If the second of three points is strictly between the other two, the angle at that point
(reversed) is π.

Given three nonzero vectors, adding the angles between them in cyclic order, with the first
vector in each angle negated, results in π. If the vectors add to 0, this is a version of the
sum of the angles of a triangle.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] [inst_2 : Fact (Module.finrank ℝ V = 2)]
  (o : Orientation ℝ V (Fin 2)) {x y z : V},
  x ≠ 0 → y ≠ 0 → z ≠ 0 → o.oangle (-x) y + o.oangle (-y) z + o.oangle (-z) x = ↑Real.pi
name: Orientation.oangle_add_cyc3_neg_left
docString:
Given three nonzero vectors, adding the angles between them in cyclic order, with the first
vector in each angle negated, results in π. If the vectors add to 0, this is a version of the
sum of the angles of a triangle.

The angle at a point is at most π.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] (p1 p2 p3 : P), EuclideanGeometry.angle p1 p2 p3 ≤ Real.pi
name: EuclideanGeometry.angle_le_pi
docString: The angle at a point is at most π.

An angle in a right-angled triangle is at most `π / 2`, version subtracting vectors.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] {x y : V},
  inner x y = 0 → InnerProductGeometry.angle x (x - y) ≤ Real.pi / 2
name: InnerProductGeometry.angle_sub_le_pi_div_two_of_inner_eq_zero
docString: An angle in a right-angled triangle is at most `π / 2`, version subtracting vectors.

If the second of three points is strictly between the other two, the oriented angle at that
point is π.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] [hd2 : Fact (Module.finrank ℝ V = 2)] [inst_4 : Module.Oriented ℝ V (Fin 2)]
  {p₁ p₂ p₃ : P}, Sbtw ℝ p₁ p₂ p₃ → EuclideanGeometry.oangle p₁ p₂ p₃ = ↑Real.pi
name: Sbtw.oangle₁₂₃_eq_pi
docString:
If the second of three points is strictly between the other two, the oriented angle at that
point is π.

Converse of "angles in same segment are equal" and "opposite angles of a cyclic quadrilateral
add to π", for oriented angles mod π.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] [hd2 : Fact (Module.finrank ℝ V = 2)] [inst_4 : Module.Oriented ℝ V (Fin 2)]
  {p₁ p₂ p₃ p₄ : P},
  2 • EuclideanGeometry.oangle p₁ p₂ p₄ = 2 • EuclideanGeometry.oangle p₁ p₃ p₄ →
    ¬Collinear ℝ {p₁, p₂, p₄} → EuclideanGeometry.Cospherical {p₁, p₂, p₃, p₄}
name: EuclideanGeometry.cospherical_of_two_zsmul_oangle_eq_of_not_collinear
docString:
Converse of "angles in same segment are equal" and "opposite angles of a cyclic quadrilateral
add to π", for oriented angles mod π.

If the second of three points is strictly between the other two, the oriented angle at that
point (reversed) is π.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] [hd2 : Fact (Module.finrank ℝ V = 2)] [inst_4 : Module.Oriented ℝ V (Fin 2)]
  {p₁ p₂ p₃ : P}, Sbtw ℝ p₁ p₂ p₃ → EuclideanGeometry.oangle p₃ p₂ p₁ = ↑Real.pi
name: Sbtw.oangle₃₂₁_eq_pi
docString:
If the second of three points is strictly between the other two, the oriented angle at that
point (reversed) is π.

Oriented angle version of "angles in same segment are equal" and "opposite angles of a
cyclic quadrilateral add to π", for oriented angles mod π (for which those are the same result),
represented here as equality of twice the angles.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] [hd2 : Fact (Module.finrank ℝ V = 2)] [inst_4 : Module.Oriented ℝ V (Fin 2)]
  {p₁ p₂ p₃ p₄ : P},
  EuclideanGeometry.Cospherical {p₁, p₂, p₃, p₄} →
    p₂ ≠ p₁ →
      p₂ ≠ p₄ → p₃ ≠ p₁ → p₃ ≠ p₄ → 2 • EuclideanGeometry.oangle p₁ p₂ p₄ = 2 • EuclideanGeometry.oangle p₁ p₃ p₄
name: EuclideanGeometry.Cospherical.two_zsmul_oangle_eq
docString:
Oriented angle version of "angles in same segment are equal" and "opposite angles of a
cyclic quadrilateral add to π", for oriented angles mod π (for which those are the same result),
represented here as equality of twice the angles.

The angle between two vectors is at most π.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] (x y : V),
  InnerProductGeometry.angle x y ≤ Real.pi
name: InnerProductGeometry.angle_le_pi
docString: The angle between two vectors is at most π.

The sum of the angles of a possibly degenerate triangle (where the
two given sides are nonzero), vector angle form.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] {x y : V},
  x ≠ 0 →
    y ≠ 0 →
      InnerProductGeometry.angle x y + InnerProductGeometry.angle x (x - y) + InnerProductGeometry.angle y (y - x) =
        Real.pi
name: InnerProductGeometry.angle_add_angle_sub_add_angle_sub_eq_pi
docString:
The sum of the angles of a possibly degenerate triangle (where the
two given sides are nonzero), vector angle form.

Converse of "angles in same segment are equal" and "opposite angles of a cyclic quadrilateral
add to π", for oriented angles mod π, with a "concyclic" conclusion.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] [hd2 : Fact (Module.finrank ℝ V = 2)] [inst_4 : Module.Oriented ℝ V (Fin 2)]
  {p₁ p₂ p₃ p₄ : P},
  2 • EuclideanGeometry.oangle p₁ p₂ p₄ = 2 • EuclideanGeometry.oangle p₁ p₃ p₄ →
    ¬Collinear ℝ {p₁, p₂, p₄} → EuclideanGeometry.Concyclic {p₁, p₂, p₃, p₄}
name: EuclideanGeometry.concyclic_of_two_zsmul_oangle_eq_of_not_collinear
docString:
Converse of "angles in same segment are equal" and "opposite angles of a cyclic quadrilateral
add to π", for oriented angles mod π, with a "concyclic" conclusion.

The angle at the apex of an isosceles triangle is `π` minus twice a base angle, oriented
angle-at-point form where the apex is given as the center of a circle.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] [hd2 : Fact (Module.finrank ℝ V = 2)] [inst_4 : Module.Oriented ℝ V (Fin 2)]
  {s : EuclideanGeometry.Sphere P} {p₁ p₂ : P},
  p₁ ∈ s →
    p₂ ∈ s → p₁ ≠ p₂ → EuclideanGeometry.oangle p₁ s.center p₂ = ↑Real.pi - 2 • EuclideanGeometry.oangle s.center p₂ p₁
name: EuclideanGeometry.Sphere.oangle_eq_pi_sub_two_zsmul_oangle_center_left
docString:
The angle at the apex of an isosceles triangle is `π` minus twice a base angle, oriented
angle-at-point form where the apex is given as the center of a circle.

If the angle between two vectors is π, the angles between those
vectors and a third vector add to π.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] {x y : V} (z : V),
  InnerProductGeometry.angle x y = Real.pi → InnerProductGeometry.angle x z + InnerProductGeometry.angle y z = Real.pi
name: InnerProductGeometry.angle_add_angle_eq_pi_of_angle_eq_pi
docString:
If the angle between two vectors is π, the angles between those
vectors and a third vector add to π.

The angle at the apex of an isosceles triangle is `π` minus twice a base angle, oriented
vector angle form.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] [inst_2 : Fact (Module.finrank ℝ V = 2)]
  (o : Orientation ℝ V (Fin 2)) {x y : V}, x ≠ y → ‖x‖ = ‖y‖ → o.oangle y x = ↑Real.pi - 2 • o.oangle (y - x) y
name: Orientation.oangle_eq_pi_sub_two_zsmul_oangle_sub_of_norm_eq
docString:
The angle at the apex of an isosceles triangle is `π` minus twice a base angle, oriented
vector angle form.

The angle ∠AAB at a point is always `π / 2`.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] (p₀ p : P), EuclideanGeometry.angle p₀ p₀ p = Real.pi / 2
name: EuclideanGeometry.angle_self_left
docString: The angle ∠AAB at a point is always `π / 2`.

The angle at the apex of an isosceles triangle is `π` minus twice a base angle, oriented
angle-at-point form.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_1 : InnerProductSpace ℝ V] [inst_2 : MetricSpace P]
  [inst_3 : NormedAddTorsor V P] [hd2 : Fact (Module.finrank ℝ V = 2)] [inst_4 : Module.Oriented ℝ V (Fin 2)]
  {p₁ p₂ p₃ : P},
  p₂ ≠ p₃ →
    dist p₁ p₂ = dist p₁ p₃ → EuclideanGeometry.oangle p₃ p₁ p₂ = ↑Real.pi - 2 • EuclideanGeometry.oangle p₁ p₂ p₃
name: EuclideanGeometry.oangle_eq_pi_sub_two_zsmul_oangle_of_dist_eq
docString:
The angle at the apex of an isosceles triangle is `π` minus twice a base angle, oriented
angle-at-point form.
